title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer interest-bearing transaction accounts with up to 24 transfers per month. Additionally, the Act addresses the payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at Federal Reserve Banks, with regulations set by the Board regarding payment and distribution of earnings. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at Federal Reserve Banks. Depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility have responsibilities for crediting and distributing earnings. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies, corporations organized under section 25A, branches or agencies of foreign banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances at Federal Reserve Banks. Amendments include authorizing pass-through reserves for member banks and making technical and conforming changes to the Act. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 5 involves the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer necessary sums to the Board for deposit in the Treasury's general fund. The Board will determine the amount each bank pays in each fiscal year. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, Federal Reserve banks are prohibited from replenishing surplus funds by the amount of any transfer made to the Treasury. Any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of paid-in capital and surplus of member banks will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
